awd_titl_txt: PFI:BIC - A Smart GIC-Resilient Power Grid: Cognitive Control Enabled by Data Mining at the Nexus of Space Weather, Geophysics and Power Systems Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The North American power grid is potentially at risk of collapse from large geomagnetic storms manifested from solar flares that generate geomagnetically induced currents (GICs) to flow in the power grid. In 2008, with the signing of the American Recovery Act, a $328M investment was made for the installation of high speed sensors called synchrophasors. These generalized power sensors provided, for the very first time, a system potentially capable of wide area situational awareness for the grid. By developing algorithms that interrogate these existing sensor arrays, combining them with real-time predictions of GICs in the power grid determined from real-time geomagnetic field data that is input to information on 3-D ground (crust and mantle) electrical conductivity structure obtained from the NSF EarthScope Magnetotelluric Program, a "Smart Service System" will be developed that will be capable of predicting impact severity on individual power grid transformers. This project will provide an important new tool for mitigating the impact of GICs on the power grid, improving the reliability of electric power service, potentially reducing the possibility of catastrophic blackouts, and reducing costs to power utilities and consumers by extending the service life of key components of the grid.

The NSF EarthScope Magnetotelluric Program has systematically measured the electromagnetic impedance of the ground at a temporary grid of stations that currently encompasses more than half of the continental US. The impedance, a frequency dependent tensor sensitive to the 3-D electrical conductivity structure of the Earth?s crust and mantle projects the ground magnetic fields into electric fields at that location. We will apply real-time streams of data from magnetic observatories to determine real-time magnetic fields at the sites of previously occupied EarthScope stations, and by projecting these through the impedance tensors and interpolating the predicted ground electric fields onto power transmission line paths, voltages that drive GICs in power grid transformers can be estimated in real-time and used as input to improved grid power flow simulations that will be developed under project support. This will be integrated with power flow information from mining synchrophasor sensor networks, and with satellite space weather data and NOAA geomagnetic activity forecasts. Human factors engineering will study power utility control room operator interactions with the data flow and user interface developed under project support, with iterative improvements of those interfaces made, given human factors feedback.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The electric power grid is the underlying foundation of our nation’s critical infrastructure, yet it is ageing and operates under increasing demands. Electric current systems in the ionosphere, generated in response to variations in the intensity of charged particles emitted from the sun (space weather), induce geomagnetically induced currents (GICs) to flow in the crust and upper mantle. The intensity of, and direction in which the GICs flow, and the electric field at ground level that results is impacted directly by the complexity of the electrical conductivity structure of the crust and mantle. High voltage power transmission lines are grounded to the Earth, so GICs flow through the transmission lines causing high voltage transformers to heat and vibrate, the power transmission frequency to distort, and reactive losses of generated power to take place during transmission. 

During extreme space weather events, transformers can fail, and power disruptions can occur leading to brown-outs and black-outs, potentially in the most extreme cases on regional or continental scale. To mitigate risk to the power grid, electric utilities monitor geomagnetic disturbance activity, and some also monitor GIC intensity directly in the power grid. When conditions warrant it, given sufficient warning utilities can reconfigure power grid parameters to direct current flow around high-risk transformers. 

In this research effort we developed methods to improve the information available to power utilities by combining information on the 3-D variations of the electrical structure and the electromagnetic impedance beneath the conterminous US crust and mantle, real-time streams of data from magnetic observatories, non-linear filter algorithms that we developed to predict the electric field at ground level beneath the power transmission lines that make use of the aforementioned data, and big data mining to interrogate sensors on the power grid. The end-product of this work is a capacity to generate continuous, real-time streams of estimated ground level electric fields all along the path of electric transmission lines. These estimates are then integrated along the transmission line paths to determine the voltage due to GICs at the locations of power substations. Finally, by using open-source quasi-DC powerflow simulation software, GIC intensity can be estimated for any substation location within the national power grid for which power utilities provide power grid configuration parameters. 

While the impact of COVID on the main project industry partner led us to pivot away from developing a graphical user interface “cockpit” that would be made available to power utilities to view real-time estimates of GICs, instead we collaborated with the US Geological Survey in their work with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to provide a real-time national map of ground-level electric field estimates for use by power utilities. Also by using Machine Learning we demonstrated that a permanent array of ground level magnetic (and ideally electric) field monitoring stations of sufficient density can accurately forecast at least 30-minutes into the future the ground level magnetic fields due to space weather, at least for event of moderate intensity. By using such forecasts as input into the aforementioned data flow, forecasts of future GIC intensity at power utility substations can be foreseen.

Broader Impacts

This research project lies at the nexus of solid earth geophysics, space weather/heliophysics, power engineering and operational management of critical infrastructure. The ability to better forecast impending damage to the high-voltage transformers that underpin the power grid has wide impact across society. Disruptions to the power supply have a first-order impact on human health and safety, on the economy and on national security. The long-term interruption of power on a regional or national scale is a disaster of first order, interrupting the supply of water, fuel, food, medical supplies and other vital requirements, disrupting communications and transportation, and leading to mass casualty events. By mitigating risk to the power grid from the impacts of space weather, we reduce the potential for wide-scale disaster
